title: Periodic Trends üìä
ques:
Compare Na, Mg, and Al for:
1. Atomic radius trend
2. Ionization energy trend
3. Explain why electronegativity increases left to right

answer.content:
**1. Atomic Radius:** Na > Mg > Al (decreases across period - more protons, same shell)

**2. Ionization Energy:** Al > Mg > Na (more protons hold electrons tighter)

**3. Electronegativity increases** because nuclear charge increases while shielding stays constant ‚Üí stronger pull on bonding electrons

explanation: **Periodic trends** result from nuclear charge vs electron shielding. Moving right: more protons, same shielding = stronger pull.

title: Coordination Compounds üî∑
ques:
For [Cu(NH‚ÇÉ)‚ÇÑ]¬≤‚Å∫:

1. Identify central metal and ligands
2. What is the coordination number?
3. Explain why this complex is blue

answer.content:
**1.** Central metal: Cu¬≤‚Å∫; Ligands: 4 NH‚ÇÉ molecules

**2. Coordination number:** 4 (four ligand bonds)

**3. Blue color:** d-d electron transitions; Cu¬≤‚Å∫ has unpaired d electrons that absorb orange light ‚Üí we see the complementary blue color

explanation: **Coordination complexes** show color due to d-orbital splitting. The energy gap determines which wavelength is absorbed.

title: Electronegativity Application üß≤
ques:
Arrange these bonds by polarity: C-H, O-H, N-H, F-H

1. Order from least to most polar
2. Which would have highest boiling point compound?
3. Why is HF not the strongest acid?

answer.content:
**1. Polarity order:** C-H < N-H < O-H < F-H

**2. Highest bp:** HF (strong hydrogen bonding despite small size)

**3. HF not strongest acid** because F-H bond is very strong (hard to break) despite high polarity. HI is stronger acid (weak H-I bond).

explanation: **Acid strength** depends on bond strength, not just polarity. Weaker bonds are easier to break, releasing H‚Å∫ more readily.

title: Buffer Solutions üíß

**3. Blood buffers** (carbonate system) maintain pH 7.35-7.45; deviation causes acidosis/alkalosis
